SubTopics: Ask and answer questions to demonstrate understanding of a text, referring explicitly to the text as the basis for the answers.
Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, distinguishing literal from nonliteral language.
Content: THIS PROBLEM HAS TWO PARTS.
What does CROSS mean as it is used in paragraph 28 of “Johnny Chuck Finds the Best Thing in the World”?

A.Choice: excited

B.Choice: lost

C.Choice: upset

D.Choice: scared

Content: Which statement BEST supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “... ran this way and ran that way ...”

B.Choice: “... hadn't found the Best Thing in the World.”

C.Choice: “... they started up the Lone Little Path ...”

D.Choice: “They didn't hurry now ...”

SubTopics: Ask and answer questions to demonstrate understanding of a text, referring explicitly to the text as the basis for the answers.
Recount stories, including fables, folktales, and myths from diverse cultures; determine the central message, lesson, or moral and explain how it is conveyed through key details in the text.
Describe characters in a story (e.g., their traits, motivations, or feelings) and explain how their actions contribute to the sequence of events.
Content: THIS PROBLEM HAS TWO PARTS.
How do the details in the story show the idea of “Con-tent-ment”?

A.Choice: through describing what Johnny Chuck does at his home

B.Choice: through the question that Johnny Chuck asks in the story

C.Choice: through the explanation of the animals' hunger after their search

D.Choice: through the listing of all the animals that join the group

Content: Which detail from “Johnny Chuck Finds the Best Thing in the World” supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “By and by they all came to the house of Johnny Chuck.” (paragraph 22)

B.Choice: “... played all day among the flowers with the Merry Little Breezes of Old Mother West Wind ...” (paragraph 26)

C.Choice: “... Striped Chipmunk and Peter Rabbit and Bobby Raccoon and Jimmy Skunk and Reddy Fox ran this way and ran that way over the Green Meadows trying to find the Best Thing in the World.”

D.Choice: “Peter Rabbit hadn't found so much as the leaf of a cabbage.” (paragraph 28)

SubTopics: Ask and answer questions to demonstrate understanding of a text, referring explicitly to the text as the basis for the answers.
Recount stories, including fables, folktales, and myths from diverse cultures; determine the central message, lesson, or moral and explain how it is conveyed through key details in the text.
Content: THIS PROBLEM HAS TWO PARTS.
What is the moral of “Johnny Chuck Finds the Best Thing in the World”?

A.Choice: Sometimes you can find happiness by following others.

B.Choice: You will usually be happy when you are by yourself.

C.Choice: Sometimes you must search for happiness.

D.Choice: You can be happy with what you have.

Content: Which detail from the story BEST supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “'Where are you going in such a hurry?' asked Johnny Chuck.” (paragraph 23)

B.Choice: “'Why I don't know of anything better than my own little home and the warm sunshine and the beautiful blue sky.'” (paragraph 25)

C.Choice: “The sun was very, very warm and they ran so far and they ran so fast ...” (paragraph 27)

D.Choice: “When the long day was over they started up the Lone Little Path past Johnny Chuck's house to their own homes.” (paragraph 28)

SubTopics: Ask and answer questions to demonstrate understanding of a text, referring explicitly to the text as the basis for the answers.
Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, distinguishing literal from nonliteral language.
Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning word and phrases based on grade 3 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: THIS PROBLEM HAS TWO PARTS.
What does the phrase HIS TEETH JIGGLED in paragraph 14 show about Pinkerton?

A.Choice: Pinkerton feels pain.

B.Choice: Pinkerton feels tired.

C.Choice: Pinkerton feels excited.

D.Choice: Pinkerton feels nervous.

Content: Which detail from “Me First” shows another example of the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “Soon he heard the voice again, closer and louder this time.” (paragraph 9)

B.Choice: “His imagination almost burst.” (paragraph 10)

C.Choice: “He landed face to face with a small creature...” (paragraph 12)

D.Choice: “Pinkerton waited. One second. Two seconds.” (paragraph 16)

Topics: Reading Literature - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Ask and answer questions to demonstrate understanding of a text, referring explicitly to the text as the basis for the answers.
Make connections between the text of a story or drama and a visual or oral presentation of the text, identifying where each version reflects specific descriptions and directions in the text.
Content: THIS PROBLEM HAS TWO PARTS.
problems/NJG3E/media/S2B.jpg
Which statement BEST describes what the picture adds to the story? T

A.Choice: The picture shows that Pinkerton is hungry.

B.Choice: The picture shows that the other Scouts are upset at Pinkerton.

C.Choice: The picture shows that the Scouts take different items to the beach.

D.Choice: The picture shows that Pinkerton has learned how to behave.

Content: Which sentence from the story BEST supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “He would do anything to be first, even if it meant bouncing off bellies, stepping on snouts, or tying tails.” (paragraph 1)

B.Choice: “One Saturday, Pinkerton's Pig Scout troop went on a day trip to the beach.” (paragraph 5)

C.Choice: “After lunch the Pig Scouts decided to go for a hike.” (paragraph 7)

D.Choice: “He was just in time to catch the bus.” (paragraph 37)

SubTopics: Ask and answer questions to demonstrate understanding of a text, referring explicitly to the text as the basis for the answers.
Describe characters in a story (e.g., their traits, motivations, or feelings) and explain how their actions contribute to the sequence of events.
Content: THIS PROBLEM HAS TWO PARTS.
How do Pinkerton's actions lead him to be tricked by the Sandwitch?

A.Choice: Pinkerton thinks only about himself, so he keeps the Scouts from meeting the Sandwitch.

B.Choice: Pinkerton cares more about eating than helping his fellow Scouts, so he keeps the Sandwitch a secret.

C.Choice: Pinkerton wants to be better than the other Scouts, so he volunteers to help the Sandwitch.

D.Choice: Pinkerton wants to arrive before everyone, so he runs ahead of the Scouts toward the sound of the Sandwitch's voice.

Content: Which detail from “Me First” supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “Pinkerton was first on the bus and sat in the front row.” (paragraph 5)

B.Choice: “As the Pig Scouts marched across the sand, they heard a faint voice far in the distance.” (paragraph 7)

C.Choice: “'ME FIRST!' cried Pinkerton, kicking up sand and leaving the other Pig Scouts far behind.” (paragraph 10)

D.Choice: “A slab of cheese! A blob of mayo! A smear of mustard. All for ME! FIRST!” (paragraph 10)

SubTopics: Ask and answer questions to demonstrate understanding of a text, referring explicitly to the text as the basis for the answers.
Describe characters in a story (e.g., their traits, motivations, or feelings) and explain how their actions contribute to the sequence of events.
Write informative/explanatory texts to examine a topic and convey ideas and information clearly.
With guidance and support from adults, produce writing in which the development and organization are appropriate to task and purpose.
Content: Old Mother West Wind and the Sandwitch both try to teach important lessons to characters in the stories.

Write an essay that explains how Old Mother West Wind's and the Sandwitch's words and actions are important to the plots of the stories. Use what you learned about the characters to support your essay.

SubTopics: Ask and answer questions to demonstrate understanding of a text, referring explicitly to the text as the basis for the answers.
Determine the meaning of general academic and domain-specific words and phrases in a text relevant to a grade 3 topic or subject area.
Content: THIS PROBLEM HAS TWO PARTS.
What is the meaning of the word THRIVING as it is used in paragraph 14 of the article?

A.Choice: watching

B.Choice: hunting

C.Choice: doing well

D.Choice: having fun

Content: Which phrase from the article helps the reader understand the meaning of the word THRIVING?

A.Choice: “... scattered among 11 packs ...” (paragraph 14)

B.Choice: “Elsewhere in the west ...” (paragraph 14)

C.Choice: “... made an amazing comeback ...” (paragraph 14)

D.Choice: “... are the animals truly safe ...” (paragraph 15)

SubTopics: Ask and answer questions to demonstrate understanding of a text, referring explicitly to the text as the basis for the answers.
Determine the main idea of a text; recount the key details and explain how they support the main idea.
Content: THIS PROBLEM HAS TWO PARTS.
What is a MAIN idea of “A Howling Success”?

A.Choice: Wolves have been missing from Yellowstone for over 70 years.

B.Choice: Many people feared wolves and wanted them out of the park.

C.Choice: Wolves helped control the number of elk living in the park.

D.Choice: Scientists helped increase the number of wolves in Yellowstone.

Content: Which detail from the article BEST supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “They worried that the predators would attack their cows, sheep, horses ... ” (paragraph 4)

B.Choice: “Then things began to change.” (paragraph 5)

C.Choice: “... living wolf-free in Yellowstone for many years.” (paragraph 10)

D.Choice: “... captured 17 more adult wolves in Canada and released them into the park.” (paragraph 12)

SubTopics: Ask and answer questions to demonstrate understanding of a text, referring explicitly to the text as the basis for the answers.
Use text features and search tools (e.g., key words, sidebars, hyperlinks) to locate information relevant to a given topic efficiently.
Content: THIS PROBLEM HAS TWO PARTS.
Which section from “A Howling Success” introduces how the scientists helped the wolves feel comfortable in the park?

A.Choice: THE COMEBACK BEGINS

B.Choice: CATCH AND RELEASE

C.Choice: EARLY SUCCESS

D.Choice: TRACKING THE PACKS

Content: Which statement from the article supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: Wolves were brought to Yellowstone and put in outdoor pens.

B.Choice: Wolves released in Yellowstone are doing well.

C.Choice: A law was passed in 1973 to protect endangered animals.

D.Choice: Several wolf packs in Yellowstone had puppies.

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Ask and answer questions to demonstrate understanding of a text, referring explicitly to the text as the basis for the answers.
Use information gained from illustrations (e.g., maps, photographs) and the words in a text to demonstrate understanding of the text (e.g., where, when, why, and how key events occur).
Content: THIS PROBLEM HAS TWO PARTS.
Look at the second photograph. What additional information about wolves is learned from the photograph?

A.Choice: Wolves sometimes howl before eating a meal.

B.Choice: Elk sometimes enter a river to get away from wolves.

C.Choice: Wolves follow their prey until the prey gets tired.

D.Choice: Elk are better swimmers than wolves.

Content: Which words from the caption BEST support the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “WAITING GAME ...”

B.Choice: “... wolves pace nearby ...”

C.Choice: “... elk finds safety ...”

D.Choice: “... the pack gives up the hunt ...”

SubTopics: Ask and answer questions to demonstrate understanding of a text, referring explicitly to the text as the basis for the answers.
Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning word and phrases based on grade 3 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: THIS PROBLEM HAS TWO PARTS.
What is the meaning of the phrase WIPED OUT as it is used in paragraph 3 of the article “The Missing Lynx”?

A.Choice: destroyed

B.Choice: made very tired

C.Choice: hidden

D.Choice: pushed away

Content: Which word from paragraph 3 helps the reader understand the meaning of WIPED OUT?

A.Choice: biggest

B.Choice: diet

C.Choice: disappeared

D.Choice: areas

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Ask and answer questions to demonstrate understanding of a text, referring explicitly to the text as the basis for the answers.
Determine the main idea of a text; recount the key details and explain how they support the main idea.
Compare and contrast the most important points and key details presented in two texts on the same topic.
Content: THIS PROBLEM HAS TWO PARTS.
Which statement describes an important point found in BOTH articles?

A.Choice: Scientists brought in smaller animals to help feed the larger animals.

B.Choice: Scientists worked to return animals to their natural habitats.

C.Choice: Scientists warned hunters not to harm the endangered animals.

D.Choice: Scientists had a difficult time saving the endangered animals.

Content: Which detail from “The Missing Lynx” supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “... roads cut through the lynxes' habitat, so the cats are sometimes hit by cars.” (paragraph 2)

B.Choice: “... released more than 1,000 rabbits into the rabbitats.” (paragraph 6)

C.Choice: “The landowners wanted to hunt the rabbits for themselves ...” (paragraph 10)

D.Choice: “... also moved some wild lynxes to new areas ...” (paragraph 11)

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Ask and answer questions to demonstrate understanding of a text, referring explicitly to the text as the basis for the answers.

Describe the relationship between a series of historical events, scientific ideas or concepts, or steps in technical procedures in a text, using language that pertains to time, sequence, and cause/effect.
Compare and contrast the most important points and key details presented in two texts on the same topic.
Write informative/explanatory texts to examine a topic and convey ideas and information clearly.
With guidance and support from adults, produce writing in which the development and organization are appropriate to task and purpose.
Content: You read the articles “A Howling Success” and “The Missing Lynx.” Think about the key details in each article that show how people can help animals.

Write an essay comparing and contrasting the key details presented in the two articles about how endangered animals can be helped. Use specific details and examples from both articles to support your ideas.
